data.title: Transmitting white monolingual Anglo-American norms: A concept analysis of “quality of language” in parent-child interactions
data.meta_description: Transmitting white monolingual Anglo-American norms: A concept analysis of “quality of language” in parent-child interactions - Volume 44 Issue 4
data.text:
In our field of language acquisition, white monolingual Anglo-American values, permeates the research, which extends into public health and educational policies. As a field, we value precocious talkers: children who speak early, speak lots, and speak well. For example, Hart and Risley (Reference Hart and Risley1995) reported on the 30 Million Word Gap as an “early catastrophe” such that families experiencing poverty were exposed to 30 million fewer words than their more affluent peers. In this earlier research, the quantity of adult input was seen as a proxy for the quality of the language input. The work of Hart and Risley (Reference Hart and Risley1995) showed a discrepancy between children experiencing poverty and children from affluent homes in the amount of language a child heard from their caregivers. This research has been replicated and extended (see Fernald & Weisleder, Reference Fernald and Weisleder2015 for an overview and Johnson & Johnson, Reference Johnson and Johnson2022 for a critical analysis). As an explanatory factor, the quality of language input has continued to be called upon to explain weaknesses in children’s language development, school performance, and later success (Anderson et al., Reference Anderson, Graham, Prime, Jenkins and Madigan2021; Walker et al., Reference Walker, Sepulveda, Hoff, Rowe, Schwartz, Dale, Peterson, Diamond, Goldin-Meadow, Levine, Wasik, Horm and Bigelow2020). Indeed, many early intervention approaches build on these findings by aiming to improve the quality of language provided by parents to their children (Snow, Reference Snow2014; Walker & Carta Reference Walker and Carta2020). This explanatory factor focuses on the individual child or family unit as the source of the problem and the focus for change. This focus on the individual and the proximal environment, including parents and schools, can ignore the structural barriers, discrimination, and racism that influence the child’s development (Rogers et al., Reference Rogers, Niwa, Chung, Yip and Chae2021).

Language development research that has sought to understand how children’s development is influenced by the language used and modeled by significant adults in their environment has provided important information to mainstream children. But by focusing on measures and approaches centered on white Anglo-American values, this same research can undermine and oppress culturally specific patterns of communications within communities, including families who are bilingual and multilingual. Not only are multilingual (Kidd & Garcia, Reference Kidd and Garcia2022) and racialized (Rogers et al., Reference Rogers, Niwa, Chung, Yip and Chae2021) children and families under-represented in developmental research, the conceptualization of “normal” is guided by research from white participants living in Western, educated, industrialized, rich and democratic countries (Rogers et al., Reference Rogers, Niwa, Chung, Yip and Chae2021). We argue that how the “quality of language” is defined, how it is measured, and to whom it is applied are problematic. We used a Systematic Concept Analysis, a methodology that aims to describe and clarify concepts and relationships within systems of concepts (Nuopponen, Reference Nuopponen2010a). Our goal is to understand (1) how often is “quality of language” and related terms defined? (2) how has this concept been defined in studies of parent-child communication? (3) how have these concepts been measured?, and (4) who has been studied?

The following sections will continue to explore the concept of “quality of language,” the harms of a deficit framing to understanding child communication development, and review two complementary frameworks, Community Cultural Wealth and development across cultures, that can inform linguistically and culturally responsive research and practice.
